title: Smith's versatility and 'contagious' positivity driving Arsenal
description: Olivia Smith's talent and versatility is helping to kick-start a drifting Arsenal side back into life as they chase silverware on three fronts.
fullText:
When Arsenal made Olivia Smith the first Â£1m player player in the history of women's football, they did not think they were signing a striker.

The 21-year-old Canadian had earned a reputation as a busy right-sided winger, the kind that hugs the sideline and takes pleasure in turning full-backs inside out.

The fee raised eyebrows in some quarters - after all, Chloe Kelly had seemingly made the right flank spot her own during last season's triumphant Champions League campaign.

What could Smith offer that she - or Beth Mead - could not? As simple as it seems, the answer may well be versatility.

Smith played the unfamiliar role of number nine against runaway Women's Super League leaders Manchester City on Sunday, but looked right at home as she scored the only goal in a 1-0 win.

With three goals in her past four league games, Smith is one of the most in-form players in the WSL.

"I'll play wherever I need to be. I was running at the back line, stretching them, runs in behind and trying to get finishes on goal," Smith told Sky Sports.

Arsenal may only have thrown the smallest of spanners in City's title charge - they remain eight points clear of Manchester United with seven games remaining - but Smith's talent and versatility has helped to kick-start a drifting Gunners side back into life.

Arsenal exploited City's high defensive line - and lack of pace the back - by playing through passes either side of central defenders Rebecca Knaak and Jade Rose.

Smith beat Knaak to a Mariona Caldentey pass before rounding Ayaka Yamashita and slotting into the empty net, but originally that job was not meant to be her's.

Stina Blackstenius picked up a calf issue during the week, forcing manager Renee Slegers to find an alternative solution.

"We have been successful with Stina [Blackstenius] in the nine, she is so good with her physicality and speed," said Slegers.

"She wasn't available, so we wanted similar qualities even though Olivia and Stina are very different players. Liv [Smith] had two-and-a-half training sessions in the nine position.

"[There was] a lot of meetings with coaches, giving her the details without putting too much information in her head so she could play on intuition, because that is when she is really good.

"She picked up the role brilliantly, the goal was exactly what we wanted."

Of course, opponents rarely employ defensive lines against Arsenal as high as City did, but the Canada forward showed she can be relied upon.

"We have different options [for different opponents]. This was very specific for us today, Olivia hasn't done it for us before. But she performed really well, so of course we will see her as an option going forward."

It's easy to forget that Smith has been playing in the WSL for less than two years.

After developing in Portugal with Sporting CP, one season at Liverpool was enough to convince Arsenal to spend big.

"There is more to come â€“ she is still a young player, she is settling in the environment," said Slegers.

"It's been a while now, but don't underestimate what it takes for a player and her situation to settle and adjust to a new life.

"She's great to work with, her ability on the pitch is so good. She helps the team with her specific qualities, but she's also a pleasure to work with. She is making small steps but she is at a really high level."

Smith let her team-mates down by getting sent off during the League Cup semi-final defeat by Manchester United last month, but she has bounced back in a serious way.

Arsenal may well be 10 points behind table-toppers City, but they look a different team to the one that struggled for consistency during the first half of the campaign.

"Players getting a rest mentally and physically has done us really well," said Slegers.

"There was a big tournament in the summer which put a high load on lots of players, so the [winter] break was really good.

"They have come back with so much new energy - that reset has been really important."

Since the cup defeat by United, Arsenal have beaten Chelsea and City either side of winning the inaugural Fifa Champions Cup against Corinthians.

And even if the WSL title looks out of reach - they have eight to play and a game in hand on City - more silverware may not be beyond them.

The European champions are favourites to progress through the next round of both the FA Cup and Champions League.

"The players' investment is so high at the moment, how we work together and [stay] humble in every moment - it's really good," said Slegers.

"Now it's about working hard on developing and pushing as hard as we can for the rest of the season.

"This positivity is contagious so we want to keep it going."

Ben Haines, Ellen White and Jen Beattie are back for another season of the Women's Football Weekly podcast. New episodes drop every Tuesday on BBC Sounds, plus find interviews and extra content from the Women's Super League and beyond on the Women's Football Weekly feed

title: Ireland let Sri Lanka off the hook at World Cup
description: Ireland cannot overcome a host of errors in the field as they fall 20 runs short of co-hosts Sri Lanka in their World Cup opener.
fullText:
Men's T20 World Cup, Group B, Colombo

Sri Lanka 163-6 (20 overs): Kusal Mendis 56* (43); Dockrell 2-17

Ireland 143 all out (19.5 overs): Tector 40 (34); Theekshana 3-23

Ireland could not overcome a host of errors in the field as they fell 20 runs short of Sri Lanka to lose their T20 World Cup opener.

Having failed to win a game at this tournament two years ago and never beaten Sri Lanka, Ireland got the desired return from their spinners as the co-hosts were restricted to 104-4 through 16 overs.

George Dockrell was the pick of their bowlers and accounted for the wicket of opener Pathum Nissanka for 24 thanks to a fine catch from skipper Paul Stirling.

The rest of Ireland's work in the field was not nearly as exemplary, however, with five drops, four of them in the final four overs as Sri Lanka tacked on a further 59 runs, making the chase all the tougher.

Despite an apparent hamstring injury, Wanindu Hasaranga accounted for the key wickets of Ross Adair, Harry Tector and Curtis Campher as Ireland were bowled out for 143 in 19.5 overs.

Notifications, social media and more with BBC Sport

Seifert half-century helps NZ beat Afghanistan

England deny Nepal in final-ball World Cup thriller

With Ireland winning the toss and electing to bowl, it was an early test of how the side's spinners would adjust not only to the conditions but superior opposition

Through a three-match series with Italy and two against the UAE in their preparations, Heinrich Malan's side eventually settled upon a bowling attack missing the out-of-sorts Josh Little.

A change facilitated by the bowling renaissance of Dockrell, the decision to leave out Ireland's most dangerous quick was vindicated as the spinners stymied Sri Lanka in the middle overs.

Dockrell led the way with figures of 2-17, ably assisted by Gareth Delany whose one wicket came at the cost of 24 runs. With Sri Lanka 50-1 after the powerplay, eight consecutive overs of spin held them to just 87-4 as they were frustrated.

Having hit Barry McCarthy's final delivery of the powerplay for four, the co-hosts would not find another boundary until Kamindu Mendis brought up his side's 100 in the 16th over.

With Sri Lanka having finally saw the back of Delany and Dockrell, the partnership of Kamindu Mendis and Kusal Mendis were belatedly able to accelerate ahead, although they were helped in no small part by Irish errors in the field.

There were three drops in the space of four 17th-inning deliveries from Matthew Humphreys, who will feel his figures of 0-44 should come with an asterisk.

With Sri Lanka powering from 104-4 to 163-6 across the final four overs of their innings, Ireland's target was much tougher.

While Ross Adair always felt the most likely to open the batting with Paul Stirling, there was still a decision to be made between the 31-year-old and Tim Tector coming into this tournament.

After averaging 14 across the five warm-ups at the top of the order, Ireland's faith in the man who hit a T20 century against South Africa in 2024 again appeared wholly justified when, despite some less than aesthetic moments, he quickly motored to 34 thanks to five fours and a six.

But, after contributing two of those five drops in Sri Lanka's innings, Adair had another moment to forget when taking a wild heave at the bowling of a hobbling Hasaranga and having his stumps uprooted.

Without the thump of Adair and Stirling, who was earlier out for six after facing 13 balls, Ireland relied upon the running of Lorcan Tucker and Tector to keep the game in the balance.

The required run-rate was always on the rise though and, as Ireland tried to find the accelerator, miscues followed in their attempts to find the boundaries.

Things get no easier in Group B with Ireland set to face Australia on Wednesday (09:30 GMT), while Sri Lanka are next in action a day later against Oman (05:30 GMT).

title: Troy girls' basketball team playing with confidence behind freshman duo
description: Standout freshman Amaya Harris and Kiana Tiernan have led Troy girls' basketball to a 12-0 record in the Colonial Council.
fullText:
Troy girls' basketball head coach Will Harris was listening in closely during an interview with his star freshman players,Â Amaya Harris and Kiana Tiernan, following a game at Ballston Spa on Thursday.

When the question was posed to the two freshmen about their goals for the future, and the Troy coach noticed some hesitation, he stepped in with an emphatic answer:

"Multiple championships," Will Harris said.

That is the tone Will Harris has set for his young Flying Horses team, which is led by his daughter, Amaya Harris, and Tiernan.

"To win it all, every year," said Amaya Harris, echoing her father. "Multiple championships."

That is the type of confidence the freshman duo exhibits on the court for Troy, which is 16-2 overall this season and 12-0 in the Colonial Council.

Despite being in her first year of high school, Harris is in her third year on Troy's varsity team, having been called up as a seventh-grader - during her father's first season as head coach in 2023-24. She is a 6-foot-0 guard and has proven herself to be one of Section 2's most prolific scorers.

With a total of 333 points on the season, Amaya Harris has averaged 19.6 points over her first 17 games. She also averages 7.9 rebounds and 6.7 assists per game.

Tiernan joined Amaya Harris on the Flying Horses last season as an eighth-grader. So far this season, the 6-foot-1 forward has scored 283 points and is averaging a double-double. She boasts an average of 16.6 points per game and 10.3 rebounds per game.

"Kiana has made such a jump from last year to this year in her skill level. It's amazing to watch her continued growth, as well as Amaya," Will Harris said. " She works extremely hard at the game and really pours herself into basketball, getting better every single day. I'm just proud of them, and the work they're putting in."

The key for both young players is confidence, which they have built over the years while playing up in age during the AAU season.

"A lot of times they're playing two or three years up," Will Harris said. "So being in that level of competition really helps with their confidence, their poise and knowing that no moment is too big for them."

"The work I've put in since seventh grade, playing against older girls, that's definitely shown me that I have nothing to be afraid of," Amaya Harris said. "Regardless of my age or my size, I can do anything I set my mind to."

That confidence is on full display whenÂ Amaya Harris pulls up from long range, several feet beyond the 3-point arc, and gets nothing but net.

"Seeing her confidence, I think that's really helped our offense," Tiernan said of her teammate. "You see how she's not afraid to go to the basket and see how she plays, it pushes everyone else to be confident and to go get their shot when they have the opportunity."

Tiernan's height and wingspan help her tower over most of her opponents, as she helps Troy secure many second- and third-chance opportunities beneath the rim.

"If she wasn't here, we wouldn't be where we're at now," Amaya Harris said of Tiernan. "She's my right-hand man."

While Troy's freshman duo gets a lot of attention from opposing defenses, accumulating the number of wins the Flying Horses have this season requires regular contributions up and down the roster.

"Addie Harkin is the unsung hero of our season," Will Harris said of his junior guard. "She is one of the top defenders in Section 2, and probably the most athletic player in the area. There have been a lot of contributions from everybody, and the girls are buying into their roles and what it takes to win."

Will Harris also does his part to boost the confidence and energy of his young group, which has only one senior, Mia Magnetto.

"I think that his energy is our energy," Amaya Harris said of her dad's coaching style. "If he's excited, we're excited, and that's really what gets us going. His energy is our game."

Troy's only two losses this season have come in non-league games against Columbia and Glens Falls. It has posted impressive wins over Guilderland, Schalmont, Bethlehem, La Salle, Albany Academy, and Ballston Spa.

Troy and Columbia are both in contention for the top seed in the Section 2 Class AA tournament, which begins in two weeks.

"We're winning some games that people don't think we should win, so that target on our back is getting bigger and bigger," Will Harris said. "We have to bring our A-game every time we step on the court, no matter what."

This article originally published at Troy girls' basketball team playing with confidence behind freshman duo.

title: Is this team actually going to contend or are they just pretending?
description: DRaysBay works best as a place for community and conversation. Accordingly, in the lead up to the new season, we are posting â€œDaily Questionsâ€ in the month of February. title: RPI moves to dismiss discrimination lawsuit brought by transgender sprinter Sadie Schreiner
description: RPI filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit brought by transgender runner Sadie Schreiner that alleges she was discriminated against by being barred from entering a meet.
fullText:
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute is seeking to dismiss a lawsuit brought by a transgender sprinter who claims that the Troy school violated New York state law and discriminated against her by refusing to let her compete at a meet hosted by the school this past April, according to recent court filings.

In documents filed Wednesday in state Supreme Court in Rensselaer County by attorney Suzanne M. Messer, RPI moved to dismiss the suit brought by Sadie Schreiner, a transgender woman who formerly competed for Rochester Institute of Technology. Schreiner's suit, which was filed in November, alleges that RPI violated the New York Human Rights Law when it barred her from competing in its "Under the Lights Meet" in April 2025 out of "fear" of reprisal from the U.S. Department of Education.

RPI is seeking a hearing on its motion as soon as March 20. Schreiner's attorneys have until March 4 to file a response.

In her lawsuit, Schreiner claimed that by citing a February 2025 executive order by President Donald Trump that threatened to rescind funds from educational institutions that permit transgender athletes to compete in women's sporting events in its decision to deny Schreiner's entry in the RPI Under the Lights track meet in April 2025, the school discriminated against her under multiple sections of the New York Human Rights Law.

Gender identity or expression is a protected status under New York Executive Law.

In its response, RPI noted that its decision to deny Schreiner's entry into women's events at the meet was based on Trump's executive order, which in the months following its issuance resulted in the Department of Education initiating investigations into multiple universities.

RPI also cited the position of the U.S. Department of Justice that the order was issued as a federal interpretation of Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972, which "preempts any conflicting state laws under the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution," including the New York Human Rights Law.

"To be sure, and despite some high-profile examples and rhetoric, the occasions where transgender females seek to compete against women in college sports, while increasing, are not frequent or pervasive in the U.S at this time," RPI's response reads. "However, the application of anti-discrimination laws such as Title IX do not turn on frequency. New York State law may not penalize RPI for administering the Invitational in the very manner that federal law requires. That is precisely what the Supremacy Clause forbids."

In a statement issued Friday to the Times Union, RPI said it "adheres to federal guidance on Title IX and we are unable to comment on ongoing litigation beyond what's contained in the public court filings." Messer, RPI's attorney, did not respond to a request for comment.

Schreiner's attorney, Susan M. Cirilli, told the Times Union on Friday that she had "no comment at this time."

Schreiner, who won Liberty League championships in the 200 and 400 meters in 2024 while competing for RIT and was an NCAA Division III All-American in both events, alleges in her lawsuit that she registered for the RPI Under the Lights meet on April 8 - two days before the meet - and paid a $44 registration fee to compete as an "unattached" runner - a competitor not affiliated with any collegiate team or track club - in both of those events.

The following day, Schreiner received an email from RPI's general counsel denying her entry, citing Trump's February 2025 executive order.

"This executive order is not limited to NCAA competition," the email reads, according to the complaint. "The U.S. Department of Education has, through communication and action, indicated that it intends to vigorously enforce this executive order under Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972."

In a memorandum of law in support of its motion, RPI asserts that Schreiner's claims of discrimination "fail as a matter of law."

While Schreiner in her lawsuit alleges she was discriminated against by being barred from competing in the event, RPI's response asserts that the school "went only as far as was required by the federal mandate," in its email when it addressed Schreiner's request "to compete specifically in the women's events" at the meet.

"Nothing in RPI's communication conveyed â€“ and Plaintiff does not allege â€“ that she was barred from participating in the Invitational's events overall, was prohibited from attending the Â Invitational, or was otherwise denied access to RPI's athletic facilities on the same terms as any other person because of her gender identity," the memo reads.

The memorandum also asserts Schreiner's claim that she was discriminated against by being denied use of a public accommodation is invalid, as the state Legislature "expressly excluded" colleges and universities from being defined as such under New York Executive Law.

Schreiner, a New Jersey resident, gained prominence during the 2023-24 collegiate track and field season. The runner, who transitioned during high school, won Liberty League outdoor track titles in the 200 and 400 meters, and set a league record in the latter event.

Locally, RPI, Union College and Skidmore are all Liberty League members.

Schreiner finished third in the 200 and eighth in the 400 at the 2024 NCAA Division III championships - all while encountering protestors at meets.

Schreiner did not compete for RIT during the 2025 season, instead competing as an "unattached" athlete at meets that allowed her to enter. The day after Trump issued his executive order in February 2025, the NCAA updated its transgender student-athlete participation policy to state that: "A student-athlete assigned male at birth may not compete for an NCAA women's team. â€¦ This also applies to a student-athlete assigned male at birth competing as an individual against women. Such individual competition is not permitted under the policy."

Schreiner has multiple active lawsuits regarding her being barred from competition. She filed lawsuits against Princeton University in July and the State University of New York at Geneseo in September. Schreiner also filed a case in September against the NCAA, noting that SUNY Geneseo followed the NCAA's policy when it barred Schreiner from competing at a meet.

This article originally published at RPI moves to dismiss discrimination lawsuit brought by transgender sprinter Sadie Schreiner.

title: Pourover: Never apologize for winning
description: A win on the road keeps the conversation going.
fullText:
I canâ€™t remember who said winning on the road was hard, but clearly they are out of their mind because Mizzou made it look easy.

Winning on the road is hard. It helps when youâ€™re playing the lowest rated team in KenPom. But you should never apologize for beating anyone, especially when itâ€™s on their home court, and even moreso when you win by 19.

Up next, on the road at Texas A&M (36), then home for Texas (38), then Vanderbilt (14) at home, and Arkansas (26) on the road. Thatâ€™s just the next two weeks. Missouri was sitting at 68 in the NET heading into the game against South Carolina, but out-performing the margin by 18-20 points depending on your metric should bump them up quite a bit. But after the game they were sitting at 52nd in KenPom.

With the schedule heating up, the Tigers had to have this kind of performance. Not only for their own confidence, but youâ€™re looking a lot different at a 15-8 team who is 5-5 in the SEC with no Quad 1 wins outside of SEC play than you are a 16-7 team, who is 6-4. The 6-4 record is a marker at this point because youâ€™re in the same slot as Vanderbilt, Alabama, and Tennessee. All teams the Bracketologists consider safely in. And not just safely in but in the discussion for a protected seed.

Heading into the game it was considered a toss up and you won by 19. Vanderbilt was a 92.2% chance to beat Oklahoma at home and lost. That game doesnâ€™t really move the needle. Itâ€™s very unlikely OU is tournament bound, and Vanderbilt should look at it like more of a blip.

But the last four byes according to ESPNâ€™s Joe Lundardi (not the most accurate bracketologist but the most widely known) are Saint Maryâ€™s, Georgia, UCLA and USC. Georgia won, UCLA and Saint Maryâ€™s were playing late, and USC plays today.

The last four in were Miami (beat Boston College), Texas (beat Ole Miss), New Mexico (x Boise State), and Ohio State (play Michigan today). Then thereâ€™s Cal (lost to Clemson at home), San Diego State (beat Air Force), Virginia Tech (lost at NC State), and Oklahoma State (lost at Arizona). So with those results, the Tigers are behind those teams and several of them lost.

The Tigers are going to lost again this year. I can almost guarantee it. They might even lose at Texas A&M and break their two game winning streak. But if they want to be on the right side of the bubble they need to find a way to at least go .500 down the stretch.

Arkansas, Tennessee, Vanderbilt and Texas are the home games. A&M, Arkansas, Mississippi State, and Oklahoma are the road games. And as of Saturday morning, OU and MSU were not Q1 road games.

This is life on the bubble, and itâ€™s something we havenâ€™t really had to worry about in the past.

The last time Mizzou was a true bubble team was probably 2011. If youâ€™re a 9 seed youâ€™re not really on the bubble, and of the Tigers 6 tournament appearances since 2011 theyâ€™ve been a 9 seed or higher. In 2011, Missouri was 22-9, but only 8-8 in the Big 12. They had 9 Q4 wins (yes the Quad system didnâ€™t exist back then but the equivalent of a nothing win), so they were 13-9 in Q1-Q3 level games.

This year Missouri is 9-0 in Q4 games. Theyâ€™re 7-4 in Q1-Q3. If they go .500 the rest of the way that would be 11-8, with a 20-11 overall record.

You did what you had to do just to stay in the conversation. The margin helps juice your metrics a bit, but now you still have to find a way to win more games. There are three Q1 games on your floor, which means you probably need at least two of those. But I say just keep winning until they canâ€™t keep you out.

21. Arkansas 88, Mississippi State 68

title: Ducati still favourite after MotoGP Sepang test, but Aprilia is in its â€œslipstreamâ€
description: Ducati remains the â€˜team to beatâ€™ following the first three days of pre-season running, according to Aprilia
fullText:
Aprilia believes it is heading into the 2026 MotoGP season in Ducatiâ€™s â€œslipstreamâ€, conceding that the Borgo Panigale marque remains the benchmark in the championship.

After enjoying its best season to date in MotoGP history, Aprilia was expected to make a step forward this year and potentially put itself in a position to mount a sustainable title challenge.

But while the Noale factory has genuinely improved the RS-GP in every metric, much of its gains have been negated by Ducati, which has managed to build a faster and more versatile version of the Desmosedici GP.

Aprilia'sÂ Massimo Rivola said he can be satisfied with the job the manufacturer did over the winter, but is wary of the progress rivals have made following the opening pre-season test of the year at Sepang.

â€œI'm happy about the fact that the â€˜26 bike is better than the â€˜25. Again, it shows that Noale is quite a good company, able to make nice bikes but also improve the performance every year,â€ he said. â€œBut we can only work on our bikes, on ourselves, and not on others.

â€œWe saw that almost everybody improved. We saw Honda being very fast, Ducati being the reference again and KTM being better than last year.

â€œHonestly, I think it's going to be quite an interesting championship, again with someone [Ducati] leading. That is still the same, but we will stay in the slipstream.â€

Ducati led the way in this weekâ€™s Sepang test, with Gresiniâ€™s Alex Marquez setting a best time of 1m56.402s on the factory-spec GP26. Apriliaâ€™s Marco Bezzecchi didnâ€™t finish too far off on the timesheets, with a late effort on the soft tyre vaulting him to second behind Marquez.

However, in sprint race simulations, Ducati was clearly the class of the field, with Alex Marquez, Francesco Bagnaia and Marc Marquez all impressing with their average lap times. Bezzecchi was considerably slower than the trio, but his decision to run on worn tyres rendered any comparisons meaningless.

Asked whether he felt Aprilia is closer to Ducati than it was last year, Rivola said: â€œI can't tell you yet, we need to take a closer look because in testing it's always difficult to know how many laps that tyre had done, how much fuel was in that tank.

â€œPecco did a sprint simulation, now we can all go home - see you in â€˜27 (laughs).

â€œI think that in any case we definitely have a better bike than last year. Last year didn't go badly, so we can't help but be optimistic. The others have clearly improved too. It's still a bit early to say. Ducati will be a benchmark anyway.â€

MotoGP will hold another two-day test at Buriram prior to the season-opening Thai Grand Prix on 1 March.

With a much longer gap between the two pre-season tests than last year, manufacturers have the opportunity to analyse the data from Sepang and bring new parts for Buriram before homologating their 2026 aero packages.

Aprilia will also evaluate certain new components at Buriram, but Rivola suggested that the core of the new RS-GP is largely defined.

â€œThere will be small parts also in Thailand,â€ he revealed. â€œI think 80-90% of the package will be fixed tonight [after Speang].

â€œBut after we analyse everything at home, small details will be brought to Thailand for the very last development in order to have quite a good base.

â€œObviously, Thailand is quite a different track in terms of aero, in terms of characteristics, it's more a stop-and-go track. There will be something more [from Aprilia].â€

Yamaha: â€™2026 MotoGP bike not performing badly but engine needs more powerâ€™

How Ducati sent a warning to its MotoGP rivals at Sepang test

title: Super Bowl radio coverage 2026: Station, channel, streaming to listen live to Patriots vs. Seahawks broadcast
description: Here's how to listen to Super Bowl 60 from Santa Clara, Calif.
fullText:
Super Bowl radio coverage 2026: Station, channel, streaming to listen live to Patriots vs. Seahawks broadcast originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The NFL is down to two:Â Super Bowl 60 is sure to be cinematic as the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots go head-to-head at Santa Claraâ€™s Leviâ€™s Stadium on Sunday.

History is repeating itself in the most dramatic way possible. Eleven years ago, these two teams met in Super Bowl 49, a game that ended with Malcolm Butlerâ€™s legendary goal-line interception that broke Seattleâ€™s hearts and cemented a New England dynasty. Now, over a decade later, the Seahawks finally have their chance at revenge on the very same stage.

For the Seahawks, the road back has been defined by a total cultural shift under Mike Macdonald. While the 2015 squad relied on the original Legion of Boom, this version features a "Dark Side" defense that led the NFL in scoring defense this season. They aren't just playing for a ring; they are playing to erase the ghost of the one-yard line.

On the other side is a Patriots team that has pulled off one of the greatest one-year turnarounds in league history. Led by second-year sensation and MVP finalist Drake Maye and head coach Mike Vrabel, New England is looking to prove that the "Patriot Way" didn't leave with Tom Brady.

The narrative arc of this game is anchored by Seattle's Sam Darnold, whose career resurgence has been the story of the year. From being a castoff to leading a powerhouse, Darnold now faces the franchise that famously saw him "seeing ghosts" years ago. Alongside NFL receiving leader Jaxon Smith-Njigba, the Seahawks' offense is clicking at the perfect time to challenge New Englandâ€™s gritty, bend-but-don't-break defense that's let up only 26 points this postseason.

As Super Bowl 60 approaches, the league prepares for a sequel 11 years in the making. Whether Seattle finally gets its redemption or New England finds another hero like Butler, this matchup is destined to reshape the legacy of both franchises.

Here is everything you need to know in order to listen to Seahawks vs. Patriots on the radio.

Radio station:Â SiriusXMÂ channel 225 (Patriots), 226 (Seahawks), 88 (national)

Seahawks radio channel:Â Seattle Sports Radio 710 AM,Â KIRO Newsradio 97.3 FM

Patriots radio channel:Â Â 98.5 The Sports Hub

You can listen to Super Bowl 60 live on SiriusXM. Along with the national broadcast on channel 88, there are team-specific broadcasts for both teams; the Seahawks are available on 226, and Patriots on 225.

Those in the Seattle area can listen to the game on 710 AM or 97.3 FM, whereÂ Steve Raible, Dave Wyman and Jen Mueller will call the action. In Boston, it can be found onÂ 98.5 The Sports Hub, which is the home for all Patriots games.

Listen to every NFL Game live onÂ SiriusXM, where newÂ subscribers can start with a free first month. Subscriptions include live play-by-play for the NFL, college football, MLB, NBA, NHL, NASCAR, and more. Get 24/7 coverage with news and analysis fromÂ SiriusXMÂ NFL Radio and other sport-specific channels.

New subscribers can currently take advantage of a first month free offer. Experience live play-by-play for the NBA, NFL, MLB, and NHL, along with NASCAR and premier college athletics. Chiefs vs. Eagles will kick off at 6:30 p.m. ET on Sunday, February 8.

Super Bowl 60 will be played at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California.

Westwood One, airing on SiriusXM Channel 88, continues its legacy as the NFL's official audio partner for the 39th consecutive season. For Super Bowl 60, most affiliate stations within the competing teamsâ€™ networks must broadcast Westwood One's feed, with only the flagship station of each team permitted to carry its local coverage. These local feeds, however, remain accessible through SiriusXM and NFL+ (formerly Game Pass).

The national broadcast team is headlined by Kevin Harlan delivering play-by-play commentary for his 16th Super Bowl, with Hall of Famer Kurt Warner providing expert analysis. They are joined by sideline reporter Ross Tucker, while Scott Graham anchors the studio coverage for his 17th consecutive season.

For fans tuning in via the Patriots Radio Network, the game will be called by Bob Socci (play-by-play) alongside former Patriots quarterback Scott Zolak (analyst). Coverage is available on 98.5 The Sports Hub, the Patriots' flagship station, with their SiriusXM broadcast airing on Channel 225.

For Seattle Seahawks supporters, the local radio broadcast can be found on SiriusXM Channel 226. Coverage is available on Seattle Sports (710 AM) and KIRO NewsRadio (97.3 FM), with the legendary Steve Raible (play-by-play) and Dave Wyman (analyst) calling the action.

Meanwhile, during halftime, SiriusXMâ€™s Caliente (Channel 151) will provide live coverage and commentary of Bad Bunnyâ€™s performance at Levi's Stadium.

title: Green Bay Packers: Meet Your New NFL Draft Crush, Iowa State DL Domonique Orange
description: Iowa State's "Big Citrus" offers size and surprising athleticism. Could Domonique Orange be the run-stuffing force the Green Bay Packers desperately need?
fullText:
It may feel a bit too early to start thinking about the 2026 NFL Draft, but mock draft season will be upon us before you know it. In fact, for many fans, mock draft season started the minute the Green Bay Packers' 2025 season ended.

A lot is going to happen between now and April 23rd, when the draft kicks off in Pittsburgh. Right now, the Packers don't have a first-round pick, and they'll start their selections with pick No. 52, which is in the second round.

Not having a first-rounder in the 2026 and 2027 NFL Drafts was part of the price the Packers paid for getting Micah Parsons. They gave a lot to get a lot back in return, and that's just part of the reality general manager Brian Gutekunst will have to work with unless he's able to swing another trade and somehow get back into the first round.

So who should the Packers target in Round 2 and beyond? There are going to be a ton of names thrown around and many of them will be great picks.

Earlier this week, we focused on Iowa offensive lineman Gennings Dunker.

Now, let's talk about Iowa State defensive lineman Domonique Orange:

Orange may have the best nickname in the 2026 NFL Draft, and you can absolutely make the case that he has one of the best nicknames of all time.

They call him "Big Citrus", and there's a reason for that. Orange checks in at 6-foot-4, 325 pounds.

He's a big dude, and he knows what to do with his size.

Orange is a run-stuffer, without a doubt. He's the guy you put at nose-tackle or one technique and ask him to take up a double team. The thing about him, though, is that he's surprisingly athletic for his size.

Nobody is going to confuse him with Devonte Wyatt, who is actually a great pass-rusher for being 6-foot-3, 304 pounds, but "Big Citrus" has the quick-twitch to be able to shoot the gap, and he's good at using his hands to get blockers off him.

Domonique Orange (95) aligned head up on the RT before penetrating and eating the RB

Big Citrus with a healthy dose of vitamin C-eek and destroy. Get it? Thank you for your time

 pic.twitter.com/lybgr8haI9

â€” Anthony Cover 1 (@Pro__Ant) February 6, 2026

The Packers struggled a bit against the run this past season, averaging 117.7 yards per game given up on the ground.

Adding Orange to this offensive line would go a long way. Speaking of Wyatt, he should be healthy by the start of the 2026 season, so new defensive coordinator Jonathan Gannon would be able to pair him and Orange together on the inside. Both of those players will demand double-teams, but so does Micah Parsons on the edge.

Orange is projected as a third-round pick but the Packers would absolutely be justified taking him in the second round. Even if they don't select him at No. 52, there's a chance he's still there at pick No. 84 in the third round, but if they like him, they may want to jump on him while they're able to in round two.

PackersRoundtable also offers a fan community and message board. Weâ€™d love to have you join us to talk all things Packers. Click the â€œJoinâ€ button at the top of the page to join our community for free.

title: Arizona State baseball to kick off season against Omaha
description: Here are the events happening around ASU athletics for this week.
fullText:
There will be a lot of new faces for the Arizona State baseball team in 2026.

After reaching the NCAA Tournament, the Sun Devils faced a lot of roster turnover and returned just six players.

Of those six, three are veterans: sophomore utility Landon Hairston, redshirt junior third baseman Nuâ€™u Contrades and redshirt sophomore catcher Brody Briggs.

Coach Willie Bloomquist and his staff brought in nine transfers, including Vanderbilt's Matt Polk, TCU's Sam Myers, Virginia Tech's Garrett Michel and Cal's PJ Moutzouridis.

On the pitching side, left-hander Cole Carlon returns after becoming one of the top relievers in the country. Carlon allowed just 16 hits in his last 33 2/3 innings in the regular season, striking out 68. The coaching staff is ramping up his workload to turn him into a starter this season.

ASU added right-hander Kole Klecker from TCU in the portal. The Hamilton High School product posted a 4.49 ERA in over 150 innings and posted an 11-7 record.

The pitching staff also returns right-handers Wyatt Halvorson and Jaden Alba, who saw action in 2025.

title: Drake Mayeâ€™s new wife trolls Seattle in DoorDashâ€™s hilarious Super Bowl ad
description: Patriots quarterback Drake Mayeâ€™s new wife, Ann Michael Maye, trolls Seattle in a hilarious new DoorDash ad for Super Bowl 60.
fullText:
Drake Mayeâ€™s new wife trolls Seattle in DoorDashâ€™s hilarious Super Bowl ad originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Patriots fans canâ€™t get enough of quarterback Drake Mayeâ€™s wife, Ann Michael Maye â€” and her hilarious new Super Bowl ad with DoorDash has sent them over the top.

In the commercial, the "Queen of the North" trolls Seattle right where it hurts: the cityâ€™s famous coffee.

â€œThe biggest weekend of the year is here, and I'm ready to settle a beef once and for all â€” about who has the better food scene, of course,â€ she starts.

She reveals that sheâ€™s wearing an â€œI â¤ï¸ New Englandâ€ T-shirt and pulls out an iced coffee.

title: Phoenix Suns lookahead. Two more games before All-Star break
description: The Phoenix Suns close out their four-game homestand against Dallas and Oklahoma City in back-to-back games.
fullText:
The Phoenix Suns continue their four-game homestand on Tuesday, Feb. 10, against the Dallas Mavericks at Mortgage Matchup Center.

The Suns are 1-0 against the Mavs this season, winning 123-114 on Nov. 12 in Dallas.

The win put Phoenix two games above .500 at the time at 7-5. Devin Booker posted a game-high 26 points and nine assists while Grayson Allen scored 23 points.

Mavs rookie Cooper Flagg, the top overall pick in the 2025 draft, was limited to 16 points on 6-of-15 shooting.

The Suns then take on defending NBA champion Oklahoma City in the second of a home back-to-back Feb. 11 before the NBA All-Star break.

Phoenix is 1-2 against the Thunder, winning the last matchup, 108-105, Jan 4 at home, to improve to 21-14.

Jordan Goodwin scored a career-high 26 points, hitting a career-best eight 3s in the upset win. Booker posted 24 points, nine assists and six rebounds while Brooks scored 22 points.

Oklahoma City wonâ€™t have Shai Gilgeous-Alexander for the Feb. 11 rematch. The reigning NBA MVP will be re-evaluated after the All-Star break for an abdominal strain.

The NBA All-Star game is Feb. 15 at Intuit Dome in Inglewood, California. Booker is slated to play for USA Stars in his fifth All-Star appearance.

Phoenix will host the 2027 NBA All-Star weekend.

Have opinions about the current state of the Suns? Reach Suns Insider Duane Rankin at dmrankin@gannett.com or contact him at 480-810-5518. Follow him on X, formerly Twitter, at @DuaneRankin.

title: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce recalls preseason matchup vs. Seahawks
description: During the recent episode of New Heights, Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce recalled preseason matchup vs. the Seattle Seahawks | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
During the recent episode of the New Heights podcast, Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce shared his thoughts on the Seattle Seahawks with wide receiver Cooper Kupp heading into Super Bowl LX against the New England Patriots. He reflected on the Seahawks' preseason victory over the Chiefs.

"You could feel the energy in the f---ing preseason, Coop (Cooper Kupp), I remember playing you guys in the preseason, and I was sitting there on the sideline, that second half, watching my guys try and battle your guys" said Kelce, "Kind of like second- and third-string guys, and I'm just like, 'This team has the f****** juice.' These guys love playing the game of football, and they do it together. And it wasn't just the starters; it was the guys after that. It was all the way through the end of the game, man."

Kelce and the Chiefs' starters were mostly spectators in Seattle that day as the Seahawks won convincingly.

"When you see guys loving to play the game together, like having that energy, having that excitement, it's the start of it," said Kelce, "And then from there, you obviously have great coaches, great leaders."

The Chiefs will be spectators on Super Bowl Sunday for the first time in years.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce recalls preseason matchup vs. Seahawks

title: Broncos tried to add Sam Darnold (twice) before he joined Seahawks
description: The Broncos pursued Sam Darnold in 2018 and again in 2024, with separate GMs failing to acquire him.
fullText:
Long before he landed with the Seattle Seahawks, quarterback Sam Darnold was pursued by two separate Denver Broncos general managers, as KUSA-TV's Mike Klis noted last week.

Eight years ago, then-GM John Elway was "desperate to trade up" for Darnold in the 2018 NFL draft. The New York Giants were unwilling to trade the second overall pick, and Darnold ended up landing with the New York Jets at No. 3 overall. Elway then made the biggest blunder of his career, selecting pass rusher Bradley Chubb over quarterback Josh Allen when Denver went on the clock at pick No. 5.

Four years later, current GM George Paton pursued Darnold during NFL free agency in 2024, but the QB opted to join the Minnesota Vikings instead. Darnold revitalized his career in Minnesota, completing 66.2% of his passes for 4,319 yards and 35 touchdowns and 12 interceptions in 2024. Paton and coach Sean Payton added quarterback Bo Nix with the 12th overall pick in the 2024 NFL draft.

Since then, Darnold is 28-6 as a starter and Nix is 24-10. Darnold and the Seahawks will face the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LX on Sunday evening.

Social: FollowÂ Broncos WireÂ onÂ FacebookÂ andÂ Twitter/X!Â Did you know:Â These 25 celebrities are Broncos fans.

This article originally appeared on Broncos Wire: NFL rumors: Broncos wanted to add QB Sam Darnold

title: Where is Super Bowl 2027, 2028? Future sites, locations
description: Here's what to know about the future Super Bowl locations, next sites for NFL championship game.
fullText:
Super Bowl 60 is finally here, but some fans may wonder where it may be in 2027.

Santa Clara is hosting the Super Bowl this year and will pass the baton as it concludes the second Super Bowl at Levi's Stadium; the Super Bowl will stay in the "Golden State" for one more year before heading east in 2028.

After Santa Clara, the NFL will head to the biggest city in California for the next Super Bowl.

Here's what to know about the confirmed future Super Bowl locations.

SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles will host Super Bowl 61.

Like Levi's Stadium, SoFi Stadium will host its second Super Bowl, having hosted Super Bowl 56 in 2022. The Los Angeles Rams defeated the Cincinnati Bengals 23-20, winning on their home turf.

Opened in 2020, SoFi Stadium has quickly established itself as one of the premier facilities in the league. With a construction budget exceeding $5 billion and a desirable locale, the venue is poised to host numerous future events.

A similar trend will continue in 2028 when Mercedes-Benz Stadium will also host its second Super Bowl. The building replaced the Georgia Dome upon its 2017 opening and hosted the Super Bowl in 2019.

The New England Patriots defeated the Los Angeles Rams in Super Bowl 53, 13-3, in what became Tom Brady's final Super Bowl win with the Patriots.

The NFL has not yet announced where the Super Bowl will be held beyond 2028.

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Next Super Bowl locations: Future sites for 2027, 2028 games

title: What country has most Olympic medals in figure skating? Full standings
description: What country has most Olympic medals in figure skating? The United States leads the way.
fullText:
Since figure skating debuted as an Olympic sport at the 1908 Summer Olympics in London, believe it or not, one country has dominated the medal count.

It has historically been the most-watched event at the Winter Olympics, and its athletes have become household names.

The figure skating Olympic program now consists of five events: men's singles, women's singles, pair skating, ice dance, and the team competition, which debuted in 2014 in Sochi, Russia, where athletes in the four disciplines compete as a team.Â There are six skaters per team, one each from the women's and men's singles, one pair skating team, and one ice dance couple.

The United States is the most decorated nation in figure skating, largely due to its technical skill with the introduction of the double axel and triple loop in the singles competition. The ice dance pair of Scott Moir and Tessa Virtue from Canada have the most Winter Olympic medals in history with five (three gold, two silver).

HOW TO WATCH: Here's the complete 2026 Winter Olympics competition schedule

Canada â€” 29 (6 Gold, 11 Silver, 12 Bronze)

title: Daryl Morey discusses buyout market as Sixers move on after deadline
description: Daryl Morey discusses the buyout market as the Philadelphia 76ers move on after the trade deadline.
fullText:
CAMDEN, N.J. -- The Philadelphia 76ers are looking to move on after an uneventful trade deadline on their part. The Sixers moved promising second-year guard Jared McCain to the Oklahoma City Thunder and 18-year veteran Eric Gordon to the Memphis Grizzlies as Philadelphia found financial and roster flexibility for the future.

As the Sixers now move forward, President of Basketball Operations Daryl Morey will look to attack the buyout market as his next avenue of finding a way to improve the team. The Sixers are always looking for ways to improve the team and the buyout market is their next option as guys like Cam Thomas and Haywood Highsmith are at the forefront in terms of options.

"I think we're in the mix," Morey said without giving any indication on who the Sixers are looking at. "I think they see a really good team or a really good market. We've had a lot of conversations already. We're obviously in competition with other teams, so I don't know if we'll get the first option necessarily, but we'll be in there with getting some of the top options."

At the moment, the Sixers have some roster spots to fill. They, obviously, signed Charles Bassey and Patrick Baldwin Jr. to 10-day contracts, but Philadelphia will need to fill those spots when those 10-day deals expire.

"I mean, we have two to fill," Morey explained. "Obviously, (Dominick) Barlow was one of the signings. I think balancing it out with guard and wing mightâ€”we really want to go for best player. I mean, obviously that sounds trite, but that's true."

With the deadline done and over with, Morey and the Sixers still need to fill out the back end of the roster. The front office will now have to look at other avenues to fill those spots.

"You do want to focus on a little roster balance in terms of adding this deadline," Morey added. "We thought, yeah, backfilling Paul (George) was a possible spot while he was out, butâ€”I hate to repeat it again, the operative players that were available weren't adding in a way that was material out to what teams wanted us to give up for him."

The deadline did not produce any additions like Morey and the Sixers were hoping for, but the hope now is that the buyout market will give Philadelphia the players it's looking for.

This article originally appeared on Sixers Wire: Daryl Morey discusses buyout market as Sixers move on after deadline

title: Liverpool Starting XI vs Manchester City: Confirmed Team News and Predicted Lineup
description: Liverpool Predicted Lineup and Injury Latest Ahead of Manchester City ClashLiverpoolâ€™s preparations for a crucial Premier League showdown with Manchester City have been shaped by a blend of returnin...
fullText:
Liverpoolâ€™s preparations for a crucial Premier League showdown with Manchester City have been shaped by a blend of returning fitness, lingering absences and tactical adjustments. With Arne Slot seeking momentum in the second half of the campaign, the Redsâ€™ predicted lineup and injury latest remain under close scrutiny.

Liverpool have received a timely boost in defence, even as several key figures remain unavailable. The latest updates provide insight into how Slot is likely to shape his side for one of the defining fixtures of the season.

Joe Gomez of Liverpool takes selfies with fans in the stands Liverpool v Crystal Palace, Premier League,

Liverpoolâ€™s medical department has been busy in recent weeks, managing a congested fixture list and several long-term concerns. The most significant positive development is the return of Joe Gomez to first-team contention following a hip issue, offering Slot valuable depth across the back line.

However, Jeremie Frimpong remains sidelined with a groin injury sustained earlier in the campaign, while Alexander Isak, Conor Bradley and Giovanni Leoni continue their respective recovery programmes. Their absence limits Liverpoolâ€™s options, particularly in wide defensive areas, where rotation has been restricted.

The Evening Standard reported that Gomezâ€™s availability â€œhas come at no better timeâ€ as Liverpool look to push towards the European places. This assessment reflects the broader picture: Slot is gradually regaining personnel, but the squad is still operating below full capacity.

Fitness management has become central to Liverpoolâ€™s approach this season. With high-intensity pressing still a feature of Slotâ€™s philosophy, careful workload monitoring has influenced recent team selections and substitution patterns.

Liverpoolâ€™s defensive structure is expected to remain largely consistent for the Manchester City fixture. Ibrahima Konate and Virgil van Dijk are set to continue their partnership at centre-back, providing physical presence and leadership against one of the leagueâ€™s most dynamic attacks.

At right-back, Dominik Szoboszlai is likely to deputise once again in the absence of Frimpong. The Hungarianâ€™s adaptation to the role has been one of the quieter success stories of recent weeks, combining energy with tactical discipline.

On the left side, Milos Kerkez is favoured to start, although Andy Robertson remains an alternative depending on match demands. Slot has rotated between the two in recent fixtures, balancing experience with athleticism.

This defensive unit reflects Liverpoolâ€™s current priorities: stability, positional awareness and controlled build-up. Against a City side known for exploiting half-spaces, maintaining compactness between full-backs and centre-backs will be essential.

In midfield, Alexis Mac Allister and Ryan Gravenberch are expected to retain their places as the double pivot. Their complementary profiles have brought greater balance, with Mac Allister dictating tempo and Gravenberch offering ball-carrying power.

Curtis Jones remains in contention after a run of regular minutes, but current indications suggest continuity will be preferred for such a high-stakes encounter. Slot has consistently stressed the importance of rhythm and cohesion in central areas.

Ahead of them, Mohamed Salah, Florian Wirtz and Cody Gakpo are likely to operate in advanced roles, supporting Hugo Ekitike as the central striker. Ekitikeâ€™s recent brace against Newcastle reinforced his growing importance, particularly in matches requiring physical presence and pressing intensity.

This attacking configuration is designed to combine directness with creativity. Wirtzâ€™s ability to operate between the lines, Salahâ€™s wide threat and Gakpoâ€™s movement offer multiple routes to goal, while Ekitike provides a focal point.

Based on current fitness reports and recent selections, Liverpoolâ€™s predicted lineup is expected to be:

Alisson; Szoboszlai, Konate, Van Dijk, Kerkez; Gravenberch, Mac Allister; Salah, Wirtz, Gakpo; Ekitike.

This XI reflects both necessity and intent. Injuries have narrowed the pool, but Slot has settled on a core group capable of executing his tactical framework under pressure.

The original Evening Standard analysis highlights how Liverpoolâ€™s recent win over Newcastle has boosted confidence ahead of this fixture. That result, combined with incremental improvements in squad availability, has created cautious optimism within the camp.

From a strategic perspective, this lineup prioritises pressing coordination, transitional speed and defensive resilience. Against Manchester City, margins are fine, and Liverpoolâ€™s ability to manage possession without losing intensity will be decisive.

With the race for European qualification tightening, every point carries increased significance. This match represents not only a test of Liverpoolâ€™s current form, but also an indicator of how far Slotâ€™s project has progressed.

If key players remain fit and the defensive unit continues to stabilise, Liverpoolâ€™s predicted lineup could provide the foundation for a strong finish to the campaign.

title: Giants' Kayvon Thibodeaux loves John Harbaugh's 'old-school' coaching style
description: New York Giants LB Kayvon Thibodeaux is a big fan of John Harbaugh's old-school, no BS style of coaching.
fullText:
New York Giants linebacker Kayvon Thibodeaux is embracing the arrival of new head coach John Harbaugh, praising his "old-school" coaching style as a much-needed reset for the team.

During Super Bowl week in San Francisco, Thibodeaux made inquiries about Harbaugh, speaking with "a few older guys" who had played under him in Baltimore. The feedback reinforced Harbaugh's reputation as a strict, no-nonsense leader who "knows football and he loves football."

Thibodeaux expressed enthusiasm for the straightforward approach.

"I always like when you pass a certain age, you donâ€™t have to sugarcoat what you say, youâ€™re just kinda straightforward, white and black," Thibodeaux said, via the New York Post. "You see a lot of different cultures, different people that want to sometimes change their ways for the new generation or they want to fit in or whatever the case may be.

"For me, specifically, I like old-school coaches because they just take no (expletive), black and white, you know what youâ€™re gonna get every day. I think with a lot of young guys that we have, I think itâ€™s gonna be good for him to really get it in order."

This comes after an earlier denial in January, when Thibodeaux dismissed suggestions on social media that Giants players were calling around about Harbaugh, responding to team legend Carl Banks: "Nobody's doing this, Carl. Effort was never the problem."

His recent comments show he has since actively sought insights into the coach hired to turn around the franchise following seasons of inconsistency.

Thibodeaux, who had his fifth-year option picked up, remains optimistic about the defense under new coordinator Dennard Wilson and is relieved that position coach Charlie Bullen was retained... For now.

After a 2025 season cut short by injury, Thibodeaux is cleared medically and eager to thrive in Harbaugh's structured environment.

This article originally appeared on Giants Wire: Giants' Kayvon Thibodeaux loves John Harbaugh's 'old-school' coaching style

title: Seth Trimble says he will remember his game-winning shot forever
description: UNC only led Duke for 0.4 seconds on Saturday night, thanks to Seth Trimble's near-buzzer-beater. Trimble highlighted his electric shot postgame.
fullText:
The 2022-23 UNC basketball season was a tough, painful one that most fans likely remember to this day. A year after making the NCAA Tournament Championship Game, North Carolina missed the NCAA tournament â€“ and declined an NIT invite.

Those Tar Heels brought in a 4-man recruiting class, but only one remains in Chapel Hill to this day: Seth Trimble, a senior guard from Menomonee Falls, Wis.

Now UNC's captain in his fourth and final season of college basketball, Trimble delivered the greatest moment of his collegiate career on Saturday night against Duke.

With time expiring, Trimble caught a pass in the corner from Derek Dixon. Trimble launched a wide-open three over Caleb Foster's outstretched arms, watched it swish through the net and joined his teammates in pandemonium after North Carolina's thrilling, 71-68 upset of its archrival.

After the game, Trimble detailed what making that shot meant, particularly in the final UNC-Duke game he'll play in Chapel Hill.

â€œItâ€™s special," Trimble said. "Iâ€™m going to remember this for the rest of my life. No matter how this year ends, as I grow older, this will be something that I remember, celebrate with my teammates, see the fans storm the court. My dad found me on the court, because the game wasnâ€™t over but he did find me. Just making a play like that, last home (UNC-Duke) game, knowing how much this game meant to me was definitely crazy.â€

Trimble scored the Tar Heels' (19-4, 7-3 ACC) first five points, so his game-winning 3-pointer proved fitting for the perfect ending. Trimble ended his night with 16 points (second behind Caleb Wilson's 23), three steals, two rebounds and one block.

In a college basketball era dominated by NIL money and the transfer portal, Trimble is a rare find. His loyalty, persistence and true passion for the Carolina Blue finally paid off on Saturday night against Duke (21-2, 10-1 ACC) â€“ in a moment he'll remember forever.

title: Lindsey Vonn Crashes Out Of Winter Olympics Downhill Skiing Final
description: Lindsey Vonnâ€™s Olympic dream is in tatters after she crashed out of the Womenâ€™s Downhill final. The 41-year-old Team USA skiing legend had taken a huge risk competing just days after announcing she had suffered an ACL rupture on her knee. However, the legendary Olympian crashed near the top of the Olympia delle Tofane course â€¦
fullText:
Lindsey Vonnâ€™s Olympic dream is in tatters after she crashed out of the Womenâ€™s Downhill final.

The 41-year-old Team USA skiing legend had taken a huge risk competing just days after announcing she had suffered an ACL rupture on her knee.

NBCUniversal's Coverage Of Milan Cortina Olympics Opening Ceremony Draws 21.4 Million Viewers

Winter OIympics Have Familiar TV Feel (Yes, CNBC Still Airs Curling) But Also A Few New Wrinkles

However, the legendary Olympian crashed near the top of the Olympia delle Tofane course as she misjudged a turn, with her shoulder clipping a gate as she picked up speed. She lost her balance and crashed, with her left leg, which had sustained a significant ACL injury just over a week ago, gave way.

Vonn was heard crying out in agony as medical staff surrounded her. After a significant pause in the time trial proceedings, she was placed on a stretcher and airlifted to a hospital. It was a devastating sight, as the 2010 downhill Winter Olympic champion, who has won four World Cups in a storied career, left the snow for what is almost certainly the final time.

Competing against a field of world-class downhill skiers, Vonn was competing as the 13th of 36 racers in Cortina dâ€™Ampezzo.

BBC Sport reporter Chemmy Alcott, a former skier who was often Vonnâ€™s competition in the past, was visibly distressed by the event and noted that Vonn was given a standing ovation as the helicopter carrying her took off.

The Womenâ€™s Downhill has now resumed, as the Olympic world awaits news on Vonnâ€™s conditions.

Vonn had trained well and set the third-quickest time in practise runs yesterday. Her teammaker, the reigning womenâ€™s downhill world champ Breezy Johnson, had earlier set the fastest time and looks set to have won the gold.

Vonn was considered to be the highest-profile athlete at the 2026 Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics. She had come out of retirement to put in a series of outstanding performances that placed her among the major favorites for a medal.

title: United set-piece routine 'didn't work in training' - Mbeumo
description: Bryan Mbeumo says Manchester United's players practiced the intricate corner kick routine that led to his ninth Premier League goal of the season in training â€“ and it didn't work.  United coach Jonny Evans and analyst Kaita Hasegawa came up with the plan, which began with Harry Maguire attacking as a distraction in the penalty area.  Kobbie Mainoo then dashed forward to take Bruno Fernandes' short pass, then flicked it first-time to the edge of the area, where Mbuemo applied the first time finish to give United the lead against Tottenham.
fullText:
Bryan Mbeumo says Manchester United's players practiced the intricate corner kick routine that led to his ninth Premier League goal of the season in training â€“ and it didn't work.

United coach Jonny Evans and analyst Kaita Hasegawa came up with the plan, which began with Harry Maguire attacking as a distraction in the penalty area.

Kobbie Mainoo then dashed forward to take Bruno Fernandes' short pass, then flicked it first-time to the edge of the area, where Mbuemo applied the first time finish to give United the lead against Tottenham.

"It was the coach who wanted to practice this in training," said Mbeumo.

"Jonny Evans came to me and the guys, and we just try to hit it. We did it once and it didn't work out. But this was the most important."

A fourth successive victory moved United to within three points of third-placed Aston Villa and their hopes of returning to the Champions League are rising.

Michael Carrick has gained a lot of credit for the impact he has had since replacing Ruben Amorim last month but Mbeumo doesn't feel the form had been disastrous before.

"I just feel we built on what we were doing from the start," he said.

"I don't think it was as bad as a lot of people felt. We just work together, make the effort together and, with a big mentality, we're never beaten."

title: Vonn's Olympic dream cut short by downhill crash
description: Lindsey Vonn's Winter Olympic dream ended in screams of pain on Sunday after she crashed out of the women's downhill, failing in her audacious bid to medal in her favoured discipline at the Milan-Cortina Games.Had she not crashed in the last World Cup downhill ahead of the Olympics, in Crans Montana at the end of January, Vonn would have been a serious contender for gold in Cortina.
fullText:
Lindsey Vonn's Winter Olympic dream ended in screams of pain on Sunday after she crashed out of the women's downhill, failing in her audacious bid to medal in her favoured discipline at the Milan-Cortina Games.

The American star had been trying to claim the fourth Olympic medal of her career despite suffering a ruptured anterior cruciate ligament in her left knee just over a week ago, but her race ended after just 13 seconds in Cortina d'Ampezzo.

She cried in anguish and pain after her awful fall high up the course, medical staff surrounding the distraught 41-year-old on the Olimpia delle Tofane piste where has enjoyed much success in the past.

The 2010 Olympic downhill champion hit the firm snow face first soon after pushing off from the gate.

She then rolled down the slope with her skis still attached, which could likely cause further serious damage to her knee.

Vonn's Olympic dream now lies in tatters after her brave effort to achieve the seemingly impossible, an attempt which ended with her being taken away in a helicopter as fans in the stands saluted her with loud applause.

Her US teammate Breezy Johnson, sitting in the leader's chair, held her face in shock. At the time Vonn crashed, Johnson, the world downhill champion, was in front of Germany's Emma Aicher by just 0.04sec following her powerful run.

Johan Eliasch, the president of the International Ski Federation (FIS) who was watching the race in Cortina, said Vonn's crash was "tragic, but it's ski racing I'm afraid".

"And I can only say thank you for what she has done for our sport because this race has been the talk of the Games and it's put our sport in the best possible light."

Eliasch added: "I hope she will have a speedy recovery and back on skis very, very soon.

"A lot of people are going to say she shouldn't have been racing today (with) that type of injury. It's obviously her decision."

One of world sport's most recognisable faces and an alpine skiing icon, Vonn has insisted that she could not only compete but win against the world's best women skiers, some of whom like Aicher are nearly half her age.

Vonn said ahead of the Games that she was planning on also competing in the team combined event on Tuesday and the super-G two days later.

But that now looks unlikely, a potential long lay-off perhaps heralding the end of her comeback to skiing in her early 40s.

Vonn retired in 2019 but returned to compeition in November 2024 following surgery to partially replace her right knee to end persistent pain.

Had she not crashed in the last World Cup downhill ahead of the Olympics, in Crans Montana at the end of January, Vonn would have been a serious contender for gold in Cortina.

Vonn had finished on the podium in every previous World Cup downhill race this season, including two victories in St. Moritz and Zauchensee, and claimed two more top-three finishes in the super-G.

But retirement looms for Vonn following a disastrous end to one of the biggest stories of the Winter Olympics.

title: WATCH: On-loan Real Madrid star Endrick Felipe sent off for Olympique Lyon
description: Real Madrid star Endrick Felipe has had a fast start to life in France since completing his loan move to Olympique Lyon. The Brazilian teenager has suffered his first setback in Ligue 1 though.In his ...
fullText:
Real Madrid star Endrick Felipe has had a fast start to life in France since completing his loan move to Olympique Lyon. The Brazilian teenager has suffered his first setback in Ligue 1 though.

In his first five games for Lyon across Ligue 1 and the Coupe de France, Endrick scored five times and gave an assist. Beyond the numbers, he has left fans in awe of his ability, with the quality of the goals and his technical ability becoming a talking point in France.

However his sixth appearance has brought his first setback, after he was sent off for Lyon in their match against Nantes. As he competed for the ball on the touchline with the Dehmaine Tabibou, Endrick kicked out at the defender, and was sent off after a VAR review.

Endrick has been receiving plenty of attention from the Nantes defenders throughout, and had already been involved in battles. Lyon went on to lose the game 1-0 to Nantes, halting their good run, as well as that of Endrick.

It seems to be an area of his game he is still working on. Despite his limited minutes under Carlo Ancelotti, Endrick lashed out at defenders twice during tussles with opposition players. One of them he escaped punishment for, but he was sent off against

At this stage of his career, itâ€™s tricky to ask him to have the presence of mind of a more mature player, but if defenders feel that he can be coaxed into sending offs, then he will be targeted. No doubt Paulo Fonseca will be doing his best to ensure Endrick understands it is a skill that he must improve.

title: Isaiah Collier continues to make the most of his opportunity
description: Isaiah Collier is evolving in the NBA. He is making a great case for being one of the Utah Jazz's building blocks of the future
fullText:
One of the best stories recently in the NBA has been second-year former Trojan Isaiah Collier continuing to make the most of his opportunities. After Collier's career night, dishing out 22 assists, 17 points, and 3 steals, Collier built off that and led his team in scoring.

The Jazz have been without Keyonte George, and Collier is making up for the majority of his impact. Collier last night had a team-high 25 points, 11 assists, and 3 steals again. Collier has now had 5 straight games with a steal and a combined 13 steals in that span. It is not just his scoring output or his ability to find his teammates for good looks; he is also quite the defender.

Collier is becoming more and more of a polished all-around basketball player. Any team, regardless of how deep the rotation is, can use a guy like Collier. He is proving to be extremely valuable for this team moving forward.

The Jazz are not looking to win games this season, even after the trade for star forward Jaren Jackson Jr. and ascending young players. This team wants a shot at a top pick in the upcoming draft. This upcoming class is full of stars. Yet when you are not trying to win, it is important to allow your young guys an opportunity to develop and see which players will be building blocks for the future.

Now, after his recent great production in his starts, Collier is proving to be one of the pieces for the Utah Jazz moving forward. He is now averaging 10 points, 7.1 assists per contest, and shooting 50% from the field. He may not likely be a starting player for the Jazz when this lineup is ready to contend, but he has definitely shown he will be a key contributor in the rotation. Heck, he has shown he can be a player that steps up when stars go down with injury.

The Utah Jazz are building some special, and part of that is because of how great the former USC Trojan Isaiah Collier has been this season. The Jazz may not get any real success this season, but the next season should be one in which conversations about the Jazz look very different.

This article originally appeared on Trojans Wire: Isaiah Collier is enhancing USC basketball brand in NBA with Jazz

title: Tyler Fletcher reacts to making his Man United debut in win vs. Tottenham Hotspur
description: Manchester United youngster Tyler Fletcher has opened up on the emotions he was going through as he made his senior debut in Saturdayâ€™s 2-0 victory against Tottenham Hotspur.Tyler makes United bowTy...
fullText:
Manchester United youngster Tyler Fletcher has opened up on the emotions he was going through as he made his senior debut in Saturdayâ€™s 2-0 victory against Tottenham Hotspur.

Tyler came on in place of Kobbie Mainoo in the dying embers of the triumph over Thomas Frankâ€™s Tottenham side.

United clinched all three points courtesy of strikes in either half from Bryan Mbeumo and Bruno Fernandes. With the win secured and the visitors reduced to 10 men after Cuti Romero was given his marching orders during the opening 45 minutes for a reckless challenge on Casemiro, Michael Carrick thrust Tyler into the action.

It was a steady cameo for Fletcher, who completed all seven passes that he attempted. He follows in the footsteps of his twin brother, Jack Fletcher, who also made his debut in December last year.

Tyler becomes Unitedâ€™s 258th Academy graduate.

After the final whistle, he spoke to MUTV and revealed his delight at the outstanding achievement.

He said, â€œItâ€™s a mad day. Iâ€™m absolutely buzzing. The best day of my life, itâ€™s a dream come true. Iâ€™ve just got to thank everyone for supporting me, throughout the way.â€

â€œItâ€™s an honour to have one of those [Academy] numbers. Not many people do it. Iâ€™m grateful itâ€™s happened. To get to go on the pitch and play at Old Trafford, itâ€™s a special feeling.â€

The debutant added, â€œI found out I was in the squad yesterday, after the session. I got told you will be with the first team, youâ€™ll be on the bench. I was buzzing with that.â€

â€œI was warming up in the last five minutes and five minutes got added on. I got the call and I was like, â€˜No way is this happeningâ€™. I got told to go and enjoy it and make as many passes as you can, get as many touches as you can, and thatâ€™s what I did.â€

Asked what Carrick was spotted telling him on the touchline, Tyler added, â€œHe [Carrick] just said enjoy it. Make the most of the moment. Go and get on the ball and do what you do, try to get as many touches as I can when I was on there, so I was trying to get little bounce passes, little short ones, just to get a few touches. That is what he said.â€

â€œThatâ€™s the best moment of my career so far. I donâ€™t think anything can top it. Itâ€™s a special moment for my family. I think my mum is here, my brother is here. My dad has got a game so he couldnâ€™t make it.â€

United are next in action on Tuesday when they go away to West Ham.

Featured image Ben Roberts photo via Getty Images
